awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Sequentially Optimal Mechanism Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research in the economic theory of mechanism design. This area of economics focuses on understanding how incentives affect economic outcomes, with the goal of designing effective and efficient payment and reward plans. The project aims to expand mechanism design theory by providing a new tool to study the problems caused when long-term commitment to a contract is unrealistic. For example, online retailers, insurance companies, and banks interact with their customers over time. As these firms learn about their customers, they may want to change contract terms by making personalized offers to some customers. In the same way, governments may sign agreements about sovereign debt, but bailouts and renegotiation may change the terms of the original agreement. The new method has promise for new applications of this important area of economic theory, including a range of applications from debt and mortgage contracts, monetary policy, the design of online platforms, online privacy, and auctions for advertising sales. As a result, the research could result in more effective management methods for businesses and government policy makers.

Progress on optimal mechanism design under limited commitment has been hindered by a lack of a tractable methodology. The team will develop a new methodology based on the idea that a mechanism should encode not only the rules to determine the allocation, but also the information the designer obtains from the interaction. This means that how much the designer learns becomes an explicit part of the design. The project has three key parts. First, the team will develop this new tool, which will be akin to the use of the revelation principle in classical mechanism design. Second, the team will use the method to characterize optimal trading mechanisms in infinite horizon settings. The characterization provides a solid foundation to Coase's conjecture and the solution method can serve as a prototype to characterize optimal fiscal policy or social insurance when governments have limited commitment ability in infinite horizon settings. Third, the team will examine the optimal design of information collection policies (for example, the use of cookies) and the resulting issues of transparency and privacy that arise when firms collect information about consumers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mechanism design has been fundamental to our understanding of the properties of market and non- market-based institutions in applications such as auction design, matching markets, organization design, regulation, environmental policy, development, and the design of social insurance and fiscal policy.

The theoretical research underlying our understanding of real-world institutions presumes that the institution designer can make binding agreements. In particular, the designer chooses his policy plan once and for all and can promise not to change it in the light of new information, even if that information reveals that he would be better off by implementing a different policy. This so-called commitment assumption is suspect in important applications, like political economy and industrial organization. 

To make matters worse, in fundamental applications like bargaining, fiscal policy, and social insurance, optimal mechanisms derived under the commitment assumption are susceptible to this assumption’s failure. 

Despite the increasingly unpalatability of the commitment assumption and the reliance of our design prescriptions on it, research on mechanism design without this assumption has been stalled for lack of amenable tools. Indeed, it has long been known that the fundamental tool of mechanism design–the so- called revelation principle–fails absent this assumption (Roberts, 1984; Freixas, Guesnerie, and Tirole, 1985; Laffont and Tirole, 1988) and the tools proposed to address this failure have limited scope and have proven difficult to apply (Bester and Strausz, 2001, 2007).

Addressing a long-standing question in mechanism design, the research funded by this award provides the analogue of the revelation principle for settings in which the designer has limited commitment, that is, the designer can commit to today’s policy, but not to the future policies he will offer. This tool expands the scope of mechanism design, which can now be used to address open questions in industrial organization and public finance, ranging from optimal selling mechanisms to the design of optimal fiscal and insurance policies. Together with this tool, other outcomes of the award showcase its power in two applications outside the scope of the tools introduced by Bester and Strausz (2001, 2007).

"Mechanism Design with Limited Commitment” (Econometrica, 2022), Skreta and I develop a novel methodology for characterizing optimal policies and institutions under limited commitment. Our work returns to the more primitive definition of a mechanism as a rule that specifies how the messages submitted by the economic agents determine both the economic outcomes and how much the designer learns about the agents’ messages. That is, the mechanism encodes not only the rules to determine the allocation, but also the information the designer obtains from the interaction. Therefore, how much the designer learns about the agent–and thus, how much he can exploit the agent’s information–becomes an explicit part of the design.

In “Optimal mechanism for the sale of a durable good”(Accepted at Theoretical Economics), Skreta and I provide a micro foundation to the literature on the Coase conjecture by showing that posted prices are the optimal mechanism to sell a durable good to a privately informed buyer when the seller has limited commitment in an infinite horizon setting. Our analysis marries insights from information and mechanism design with those from the literature on durable goods to characterize optimal mechanisms in an infinite horizon setting. In doing so, we showcase how the results in Doval and Skreta (2022a) enable the first systematic analysis of mechanism design with limited commitment in an infinite horizon setting, a largely unexplored environment as in such settings, the tools of Bester and Strausz (2001) presume Markovian play.

The trade-off between product personalization and price discrimination is at the center of the debate about the use of consumer data. In “Purchase History and Product Personalization” (RAND Journal of Economics, Forthcoming, and extended abstract in the Twenty-Fourth ACM Conference on Economics and Computation), we shed light on this debate by showing that the endogenous nature of consumer data in the form of purchase histories coupled with ratcheting forces can lead to narrow product lines. We study a dynamic mechanism design problem under limited commitment. We consider a canonical yet stylized model of upstream-downstream interaction, where a consumer buys a good of variable quality upstream, followed by an indivisible good downstream. Whereas a rich product line allows the upstream firm to better tailor the product to the consumer’s tastes, it also creates a richer purchase history, which can be exploited by the downstream firm for price discrimination. In the spirit of the ratchet effect, the consumer demands upstream rents to be compensated for downstream rent extraction. We show  the downstream firm’s use of the consumer’s purchase history for price discrimination introduces a novel distortion: The upstream firm offers a subset of the products it would offer if, instead, it could jointly design its product line and downstream pricing.
